channel.title: NYT > World
channel.copyright: Copyright 2013 The New York Times Company

item.title: South and North Korea Resume Talks on Reopening Factory Complex
item.description: Negotiations began again Monday over the jointly operated Kaesong industrial park, a symbol of inter-Korean cooperation that has been closed for months.
item.dc:creator: By CHOE SANG-HUN

item.title: With a Royal Baby Due, News Outlets Are on High Alert
item.description: The birth of the child, whenever it happens — any day now, if the tabloids are to be believed — will be a spectacle unlike any other in the modern media age.
item.dc:creator: By BRIAN STELTER
item.media:description: Journalists waiting outside St. Mary’s Hospital in London to see Prince William’s first child.

item.title: Egyptian Leaders Freeze Assets of Morsi Backers
item.description: Egypt’s new military-led government is increasing pressure on supporters of ousted President Mohamed Morsi to back down from their public protests.
item.category: Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )
item.dc:creator: By DAVID D. KIRKPATRICK

item.title: Nadezhda Popova, WW II ‘Night Witch,’ Dies at 91
item.description: Ms. Popova was a member of a renowned unit of deadly female Soviet pilots called the “Night Witches” by German invaders because of the sound their plywood planes made.
item.dc:creator: By DOUGLAS MARTIN

item.title: Spain’s Real Crisis Is a Leadership Void, Analysts Say
item.description: Corruption allegations against a political party treasurer are hurting national morale and the credibility of institutions, distracting the government from economic concerns, political observers say.
item.dc:creator: By RAPHAEL MINDER

item.title: Bangladesh Pollution, Told in Colors and Smells
item.description: A deadly building collapse brought the dangers of Bangladesh’s clothing manufacturing to world notice, but the environmental destruction is taking a daily toll as well.
item.dc:creator: By JIM YARDLEY
item.media:credit: Khaled Hasan for The New York Times
item.media:description: In Savar, Bangladesh, site of April’s factory disaster, untreated factory wastewater is common.

item.title: No Quick Impact in U.S. Arms Plan for Syria Rebels
item.description: The plan calls for the C.I.A. to supply only small arms, and only to a limited segment of the opposition — the actual numbers are unclear.
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
item.dc:creator: By MARK MAZZETTI, ERIC SCHMITT and ERIN BANCO
item.media:description: A rebel fighter aimed his weapon at Syrian government forces from inside a wrecked school in the city of Aleppo on Sunday.

item.title: Memo From Spain: Spain’s Slow-Moving Scandal Edges Closer to the Top
item.description: Allegations that Spain’s leadership has for years enriched itself with a secret slush fund are becoming harder to ignore, deepening the nation’s sense of distrust and disillusionment.
item.dc:creator: By RAPHAEL MINDER
item.media:description: Prime Minister Mariano Rajoy of Spain, speaking in Madrid on Thursday.

item.title: Rebels Drive More Than 60,000 From Congo to Uganda
item.description: The refugee influx continues three days after a Ugandan rebel group attacked the town of Kamango and killed some people on Thursday, according to military officials.
item.dc:creator: By THE ASSOCIATED PRESS
item.media:description: A refugee from the Democratic Republic of Congo with her children and her belongings in western Uganda on Saturday. Congolese have been fleeing attacks in Congo by Ugandan rebels.

item.title: Brazil’s Plan Isn’t What Doctors Would Order
item.description: After President Dilma Rousseff proposed recruiting foreigners, Brazilian physicians said a lack of infrastructure and supplies was the problem.
item.dc:creator: By SETH KUGEL
item.media:credit: Lalo de Almeida for The New York Times
item.media:description: Dr. Antônio Augusto Dall’Agnol Modesto at a public clinic in São Paulo. Doctors in Brazil say the health system needs resources, not foreign recruits.

item.title: Taps in Office of Legislator in Iran Prompt Calls for Inquiry
item.description: Lawmakers in Iran said that the nation’s intelligence minister should be questioned after wiretapping equipment was found in a legislator’s office.
item.category: Wiretapping and Other Eavesdropping Devices and Methods
item.dc:creator: By THOMAS ERDBRINK

item.title: Media Decoder: Documentary Planned on Malala Yousafzai, Girl Shot by Taliban
item.description: Davis Guggenheim, the documentary-maker behind “Waiting for Superman” and “An Inconvenient Truth,” is making a film about Malala Yousafzai, the Pakistani education advocate.
item.dc:creator: By MICHAEL CIEPLY

item.title: Afghan Accused in Attack Escapes With His Guard
item.description: A guard assigned to watch over an Afghan soldier accused of shooting coalition members instead helped him escape, the authorities said.
item.dc:creator: By AZAM AHMED

item.title: Discredited Wartime Hero’s Backers Rebut Charges
item.description: Supporters of Giovanni Palatucci, a wartime Italian previously praised for saving thousands of Jews, rebutted charges by researchers who described him as a Nazi collaborator.
item.dc:creator: By PATRICIA COHEN
item.media:description: Giuseppe Pisanu, then Italy’s interior minister, during a 2005 ceremony honoring Giovanni Palatucci in Jerusalem.

item.title: Blasts Across Iraq Kill at Least 40 Amid a Surge in Attacks
item.description: The series of bombings came during the Muslim holy month of Ramadan and followed a surge in attacks that has lasted for months.
item.dc:creator: By DURAID ADNAN

item.title: Israel Increases Pressure on U.S. to Act on Iran
item.description: Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu said the Obama administration must show the new Iranian government that a military option “is truly on the table.”
item.dc:creator: By JODI RUDOREN and DAVID E. SANGER

item.title: N.S.A. Leaks Revive Push in Russia to Control Net
item.description: Even before Edward J. Snowden arrived in a Moscow airport, Russia had been pressing for greater access to social networking and e-mail data.
item.dc:creator: By ANDREW E. KRAMER

item.title: 15 Held at Guantánamo Are Said to Quit Hunger Strike
item.description: Fifteen detainees who had been listed as participants stopped taking part in the protest at the prison in Cuba, an American military spokesman said, accelerating an apparent downward trend.
item.dc:creator: By CHARLIE SAVAGE

item.title: Cory Monteith, Star of Hit Show ‘Glee,’ Found Dead
item.description: Mr. Monteith, 31, who shot to fame in Fox’s TV series but was beset by fierce addiction struggles, was found dead in a hotel room in Canada on Saturday, the police said.
item.dc:creator: By THE ASSOCIATED PRESS

item.title: Woman Gored During Final Bull Run in Spain
item.description: A regional health official said the 23-year-old woman was gored in the thorax and was hospitalized along with four others who were injured in the bull run.
item.dc:creator: By THE ASSOCIATED PRESS

item.title: Former Egyptian Ambassador to U.S. Named Foreign Minister
item.description: Nabil Fahmy accepted the post of foreign minister on Sunday in the interim government being put in place after the removal of president Mohamed Morsi.
item.dc:creator: By REUTERS

item.title: 2 Killed by U.S. Drone Strike in Pakistan
item.description: At least two people were killed Saturday in an American drone strike in a northwestern tribal region of Pakistan, according to intelligence officials.
item.dc:creator: By IHSANULLAH TIPU MEHSUD

item.title: Turkish Lawmakers Move to Curb Army’s Political Power
item.description: The Turkish Parliament on Saturday amended an army regulation that had paved the way for military intervention in politics.
item.dc:creator: By SEBNEM ARSU

item.title: Israel Airstrike Targeted Advanced Missiles That Russia Sold to Syria, U.S. Says
item.description: American officials said Israel carried out an air attack in Syria this month that targeted advanced antiship cruise missiles sold to the Syria government by Russia.
item.category: Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )
item.dc:creator: By MICHAEL R. GORDON

item.title: Japan and China Trade Sharp Words Over Islands
item.description: The heated exchange over disputed territory started with a Japanese report accusing China of aggressive maritime tactics and was stark evidence of two nations uneasy about each other’s military capabilities.
item.dc:creator: By JANE PERLEZ
